welcome.title: Welcome to PigSoil+
welcome.subtitle: We're here to help you get started and answer your questions

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.a1: PigSoil+ helps swine farmers turn swine manure into quality organic fertilizer. Track your composting process, get step-by-step guides, and connect with buyers through our marketplace.
faq.a2: Choose between Basic Swine Manure or Hot Composting method in the Batches tab. Follow the checklist and get reminders for turning, watering, and monitoring your compost.
faq.a3: Connect with organic fertilizer buyers. List your finished compost, browse listings, and communicate directly through in-app messaging. Arrange your own payment terms face-to-face.
faq.a4: Free: Every feature accessible, but with limitations to 10 Manong Bot uses weekly, 5 camera AI scans weekly. Essential (‚Ç±149/month): Everything in free, and unlimited Manong Bot uses, 5 camera scans. Premium (‚Ç±199/month): Everything unlimited including camera AI scans.
faq.q5: Can I use the app offline?
faq.a5: Yes! Access composting guides, update batches, and add notes offline. Your data syncs automatically when you reconnect to the internet.
faq.q6: How do I message sellers in products I'm interested in?
faq.a6: Tap any listing to view details, then use the message button to chat directly. Arrange meetings to inspect products and discuss payment terms in person.

Payment arrangements (cash, installments, barter) are handled privately between you and the buyer during face-to-face meetings. This approach respects traditional Filipino agricultural community practices.

header.title: Complete Composting Guides
header.subtitle: Choose your composting method for detailed day-by-day instructions

basicMethod.title: Basic Swine Manure Composting
basicMethod.subtitle: Complete 21-Day Step-by-Step Guide for Beginners
basicMethod.aboutText: Traditional aerobic composting using swine waste and plant matter. Perfect for beginners with minimal equipment needed. Creates low-cost organic fertilizer in 21 days.

day1.title: Initial Setup
day1.task: Layer swine manure with carbon materials
day1.description: Create alternating layers of swine manure and dry materials:
day1.step1: 1. Start with a 6-inch layer of coarse plant material (corn stalks, rice straw)
day1.step2: 2. Add 4 inches of fresh swine manure
day1.step3: 3. Sprinkle 2 inches of dry materials (rice hulls, sawdust)
day1.step4: 4. Repeat layering 3-4 times until pile reaches 1.2-1.5 meters high
day1.step5: 5. Water each layer lightly as you build
day1.tipText: Create alternating layers of swine manure and dry materials. Maintain a 3:1 ratio of brown materials (carbon-rich) to green materials (nitrogen-rich manure).

day7.title: First Turning
day7.task: Mix all layers thoroughly for proper aeration
day7.description: Turn pile for oxygen and check moisture levels:
day7.step1: 1. Using a pitchfork or shovel, turn the entire pile
day7.step2: 2. Move outside materials to the center and center materials to the outside
day7.step4: 4. Check moisture levels throughout the pile
day7.step5: 5. Add water if needed to maintain proper moisture
day7.tipText: Turn pile for oxygen and check moisture levels. After turning, the pile temperature will drop temporarily but should rise again within 24-48 hours.

day14.title: Mid-Point Check
day14.task: Turn pile and monitor decomposition progress
day14.description: Monitor texture changes and earthy smell development:
day14.step1: 1. Turn the pile completely as done on day 7
day14.step2: 2. Add additional dry carbon materials if needed (rice hulls, dried leaves, sawdust)
day14.step3: 3. Mix thoroughly to ensure even distribution
day14.tipText: Monitor texture changes and earthy smell development. This is a good time to adjust the carbon-nitrogen ratio if the pile has been too wet or smelly.

day17.title: Final Turning
day17.task: Check texture uniformity and adjust moisture
day17.description: Final quality checks and preparation for harvest:
day17.step1: 1. Perform thorough turning of the pile
day17.tipText: Final quality checks and preparation for harvest. Materials should be darker, less fibrous, and have a pleasant earthy smell.

day21.title: Harvest Ready
day21.task: Compost is ready for use or sale
day21.description: Dark, crumbly compost ready for application or marketplace:
day21.step1: 1. Perform final turning of the pile
day21.step2: 2. Screen compost through 1/2 inch mesh to remove large particles
day21.step3: 3. Return large particles to a new compost pile
day21.step4: 4. Test pH (should be 6.5-7.5 for optimal use)
day21.step5: 5. Check for proper moisture and crumbly texture
day21.tipText: Dark, crumbly compost ready for application or marketplace. Good compost should be dark brown, crumbly, have an earthy smell, and feel cool to the touch.

hotMethod.title: Hot Composting Method
hotMethod.subtitle: 18-day pathogen-free composting method
hotMethod.aboutText: Pathogen-free compost from swine manure through high-heat decomposition. This advanced method uses controlled high temperatures to rapidly decompose materials while eliminating harmful pathogens.

day1.title: High-Carbon Setup
day1.task: Build pile with proper C:N ratio
day1.description: Create optimal conditions for thermophilic decomposition:
day1.step1: 1. Choose a sheltered location with good drainage
day1.step2: 2. Create a base layer of coarse materials (3 inches)
day1.step3: 3. Mix fresh swine manure with high-carbon materials (2:1 ratio)
day1.step4: 4. Build pile rapidly to minimum 1.5m x 1.5m x 1.5m (critical mass)
day1.step6: 6. Insert thermometer into center of pile
day1.tempText: Create optimal conditions for thermophilic decomposition. Expect pile to reach 40-50¬∞C within 24-48 hours.

day3.title: Temperature Monitor
day3.description: Monitor temperature rise and maintain optimal conditions:
day3.step2: 2. Check multiple points in the pile
day3.step4: 4. Verify insulation is properly covering pile
day3.step5: 5. Check moisture levels - should feel warm and moist
day3.step7: 7. Adjust covering if heat is escaping
day3.tempText: Monitor temperature rise and maintain optimal conditions. Target: 60-70¬∞C for pathogen elimination and rapid decomposition.

day8.title: Heat Maintenance
day8.task: Turn pile to maintain thermophilic phase
day8.description: Sustain high temperatures for rapid decomposition:
day8.step2: 2. Turn entire pile, moving outer materials to center
day8.step3: 3. Ensure all materials reach thermophilic zone
day8.step4: 4. Check moisture throughout and adjust as needed
day8.tempText: Sustain high temperatures for rapid decomposition. Temperature will drop temporarily but should recover within 24 hours.

day12.title: Pathogen Elimination
day12.description: Ensure complete pathogen elimination through heat:
day12.step2: 2. Perform complete turn of all materials
day12.step3: 3. Assess decomposition progress - materials should be darker
day12.step4: 4. Check for proper texture (less fibrous, more uniform)
day12.warningText: Ensure complete pathogen elimination through heat. Maintain temperatures above 55¬∞C for thorough sanitization.

day18.title: Curing Complete
day18.description: Pathogen-free compost ready for use or marketplace:
day18.step3: 3. Test final pH and moisture content
day18.step4: 4. Package finished compost for storage or use
day18.step5: 5. Return oversized materials to new compost batch
day18.tipText: Pathogen-free compost ready for use or marketplace. Perfect hot compost is dark brown, crumbly, smells earthy, feels cool, and has uniform texture.
